entry.title: You will not do it later (most likely) - I'm a procrastinator, I know
entry.summary:
If you're like me, a big ass procrastinator, I'm sure you have said "I will do that later" to yourself before, right?
How many times times have you come back and done it? I'm guessing not that many times. If you do, congrats you're not a compulsive procrastinator! In my case, and probably quite a few people, we don't go back. At least not in a short amount of time. We might come back in a week or two, a couple of months, or even years after. Take this example, you've been working on a new feature. You finish it, do a refactoring pass, add a couple more tests to cover all cases and you've got just adding a couple of doc comments or writing documentation for this particular feature. You are tired and just want to finish the tasks, so you say to yourself "I will do that tomorrow" or "I wiâ€¦

entry.title: How to Govern Terraform States Using GitLab Enterprise?
entry.summary: TL;DR: With the mass adoption of Terraform and becoming the de facto tool for developers to build, and manage their cloud infrastructure at scale, most companies today, who rely heavily on Terraform for their infrastructure management, choose to do so with an orchestration tool. In this blog, we'll review the way to govern Terraform States using Gitlab Enterprise Terraform has become the nearly ubiquitous way to provision services in a cloud native era. However, when we start to build our infrastructure using Terraformâ€™s as-code approach, there are a few things we need to consider in order to be able to manage these operations at scale, for a diversity of decentralized services, and for distributed teams. At Firefly, we often encounter the challenges of managing IaC at scale, as part of â€¦

entry.title: The story of a Noob
entry.summary: The stack â€” VB6, Macros, MS Access Like I stated in the prologue, I was fascinated with tech from a very young age. What I failed to mention before is that thanks to my loving and understanding parents, my curiosity was not killed in school. Thatâ€™s mostly thanks to the fact that in my house I could always take any â€œjunkâ€ home to take apart and learn how it ticks. At the age of 13, I was already pretty good on a PC, but havenâ€™t really dived into programming yet. My first real time was when I went to a few VB6 classes and convinced my parents to buy me a book. For me it was like magic, I could tell the computer what to do and it would do it, as long as I didnâ€™t fuck it up somehow (which happened a lot at that time). I wrote small dumb things, what most would call a â€œHello Worldâ€. It was arouâ€¦

entry.title: Prologue â€” One devs journey
entry.summary:
A brief history
Itâ€™s rude not to introduce myself, so Iâ€™ll start with a little background, just to get us started. I can call myself a developer for over 15 years now, and a tinkerer for a few more. I started playing with technology from the very young age of 7, when I entered and won a race event where I built a toy solar car. Till today, as a system architect and having some successes (and failures) at tech startups, and running my own dev & consulting business. As of late, my team and I have released the first of our libraries as open source, this has made me look back at the path that led me here. My main goal is to share that story, the ups and downs (and sometimes sideways) and hopefully it will help someone on their path. I canâ€™t promise it will be interesting all the time (or even pretty), but I hope you will join me for the journey. I will be writing this as a few different posts, each one not much longer than this one, as I want it to be a quick and fun read. So this is the plan: The story of a Noob â€” My somewhat humble beginnings The journey begins â€” Teaching myself in the age before google They donâ€™t call it intelligence for nothing â€” My military career School canâ€™t teach you everything â€” My time at Uni and my first freelance work Itâ€™s time to settle down â€” My first real job Good code is like an onion, it has layers â€” The right way to write code My eureka moment â€” After writing the same code over and over, something had to change Itâ€™s ALIVE â€” My solution to CRUD boilerplate, and the evolution of the layers Shit just got real â€” Using what I learned to land a big contract Time to give back â€” The birth of my first open source

entry.title: Next.js + Playwright + GitHub Actions Boilerplate
entry.summary: A comprehensive Todo app with APIs and E2E tests with GitHub Actions enabled. See the repository: https://github.com/burakkantarci/playwright-todo-app This project is a boilerplate to demonstrate the usage of modern stacks together. The project stack: Next.js Todo App Playwright GitHub Actions Foresight The tech stack market is expanding more and more and seeing everything in action is the easiest way to see the benefits. I decided to create a combination of Next.js, Playwright, GitHub Actions, and Foresight to create an E2E stack for a web application. All the external tooling is free; therefore, you donâ€™t need to pay anything to try this stack. What will be the result A Serverless Next.js based TODO application with Upstash, the simplest way of production ready web application. Playwriâ€¦

entry.title: The need for social interaction
entry.summary: This is an opinionated article on the need for social interaction. The other day I got a message from Sandro, telling me he's in The Netherlands and asking if we could meet for a coffee. I'm always up for a coffee, so let's do it. I took the train from my town to Amsterdam, which is roughly 2.5 hours of travel. During this time you see so many people. And most of them are in their little bubble, their minds in different worlds, listening to a podcast, music, or watching a series. You'd even think they wouldn't notice it if you decide to enter the train fully naked. (I didn't try that) Arrive in Amsterdam. You quickly notice the same behavior. Everyone is walking around with AirPods, overhead earphones, and just zoning out. The interesting part is that you even see it with groups of people â€¦

entry.title: Noox.world â€” Create, prove, and mint your on-chain achievements
entry.summary:
https://noox.world/) is a platform where you can create, prove, and mint on-chain achievements as soulbound NFTs. These NFTs are non-transferable and hold within their metadata the record of oneâ€™s on-chain actions.
ðŸ¤”Â Problem & Solution:
Web3 projects all have a problem with user retention. To put it differently, purely financialized instruments are not the best incentive structure to allow for the creation of a robust and sustainable ecosystem.
Traditionally, achievements are included within game designs to provide gamers with the impetus to do more than simply complete the game. It is used to motivate players to maximize their own general score and let players obtain recognition for their performance via scores or ranks. A similar design can be applied to crypto and Web3. By unlockingâ€¦

entry.title: How to Use Push Method In React Hooks?
entry.summary: The push () method is the process of adding one or more numbers of elements at the end of the array and returning with a new length of the array. Normally, the push method helps to add the value to the array. It is a convenient option for using bracket notation for assigning one or even more key-value pairs with the object. The value gets easily assigned with the use of the push method. They are suitable options for adding the object to the end of the array. React hooks allows simpler code which is suitable for implementing similar functions faster even without any hassle. These are suitable options for implementing the React state along with the lifecycle method, even without any use of the writing class. Normally, the Push method is used using the call() or apply()objects which resemble â€¦

entry.title: Aworker â€” Web3 jobs
entry.summary:
â€œ Hey HuntersðŸ‘‹â€¨
I built a web3 job board where people can find remote jobs in web3 companies.
One more job board?
Probably.
I really do like this space. In my previous project (an NFT portfolio management tool), we got hundreds of requests from people who wanted to work there. And we didnâ€™t do listings on other job boards. So, I wanted to build platform where people know more about this space and find new opportunities to work in the web3 companies.
Also, people will be able to get tokens while they are searching for a job.
Will be glad to hear your feedback and ideas.
P.S. Special offer for PH: Jobs listing for web3 companies is free for the next 3 days ðŸ˜€Â â€

entry.title: 3 ways to take screenshots on Linux
entry.summary:
3 ways to take screenshots on Linux Jim Hall Thu, 08/04/2022 - 03:00
2 readers like this 2 readers like this When writing about open source software, I prefer to show a few screenshots to help demonstrate what I'm talking about. As the old saying goes, a picture is worth a thousand words. If you can show a thing, that's often better than merely trying to describe it. There are a few ways you can take screenshots in Linux. Here are three methods I use to capture screenshots on Linux: 1. GNOME GNOME has a great built-in screenshot tool. Just hit the PrtScr key on your keyboard, and GNOME displays a screenshot dialog:
Image by: (Jim Hall, CC BY-SA 40) The default action is to grab a screenshot of a region. This is an incredibly useful way to crop a screenshot as you makâ€¦

entry.title: Lengthen the life of your hardware with Linux
entry.summary:
Lengthen the life of your hardware with Linux Don Watkins Thu, 08/04/2022 - 03:00
1 reader likes this 1 reader likes this Sustainability is an increasingly important problem when it comes to computing. Reduce, reuse, recycle is a popular motto for environmentally responsible consumption, but applying that to your computer hardware can be challenging. Many proprietary operating systems essentially force a hardware upgrade upon you long before your old hardware is used up. If you own a computer with Windows, you've probably needed to purchase a new one to upgrade because your old one didn't meet the hardware requirements of the latest OS. Apple doesn't do any better, either. A MacBook Air I owned was essentially rendered obsolete by an upgrade to macOS Mojave in 2019. By contrast, I ruâ€¦

entry.summary:
Illustration by Alex Castro / The Verge
NBCâ€™s long-running soap opera Days of Our Lives will be leaving broadcast television after 57 years on to stream exclusively on Peacock, the network announced on Wednesday. The change means that fans who previously have been able to watch the show for free on broadcast will now have to pay for a streaming service to learn what happens next in the showâ€™s fictional town of Salem. New episodes of Days of Our Lives will debut beginning September 12th. â€œWith a large percentage of the Days of Our Lives audience already watching digitally, this move enables us to build the showâ€™s loyal fanbase on streaming while simultaneously bolstering the network daytime offering with an urgent, live programming opportunity for partners and consumers,â€ ... entry.summary:

Facebook is shutting down live shopping, its QVC-like livestream feature that lets creators broadcast and sell products to an audience (via TechCrunch). The feature will officially shut down on October 1st, and Facebook says itâ€™s part of the companyâ€™s initiative to shift focus to Reels. â€œAs consumersâ€™ viewing behaviors are shifting to short-form video, we are shifting our focus to Reels on Facebook and Instagram, Metaâ€™s short-form video product,â€ Facebook explains. entry.title: Spain bans setting the AC below 27 degrees Celsius
entry.summary:
At a press conference last week, Spainâ€™s Prime Minister Pedro SÃ¡nchez urged the country to conserve energy in every way possible, including taking off ties to stay cool. | Photo By Eduardo Parra/Europa Press via Getty Images
As Europe grapples with a scorching summer and skyrocketing energy prices, Spain has become the latest government to tell its citizens to turn down the AC. A decree published on Tuesday morning in the official state gazette and scheduled to go into effect next week mandates that air conditioning in public places be set at or above 27 degrees Celsius (about 80 degrees Fahrenheit) and that doors of those buildings remain closed to save energy. Those public places include offices, shops, bars, theaters, airports, and train stations. The decree is being extended as a recommendation to all Spanish households. The rules include maintaining heating at or below 19 degrees Celsius (about 66 degrees Fahrenheit) in the winter and will remain in... Continue readingâ€¦

entry.summary:

Luxury electric vehicle maker Lucid Motors is slashing its production forecast for 2022 for the second time this year. The Newark, California-based company announced it was revising its production expectations to between 6,000 and 7,000 vehicles. Lucid originally said it would make 20,000 vehicles in 2022, but that number was revised in February to 12,000â€“14,000 vehicles. It was another disappointing turn for the EV maker, which is strongly angling to capture some of Teslaâ€™s market share with its ultra-premium, ultra-long-range Lucid Air sedan. ï¼ˆè¿™æ˜¯æˆ‘çš„ Debian æœºå™¨ä¸­çš„é»˜è®¤é…ç½®æ–‡ä»¶ã€‚å¦ä¸€ä¸ªæµè¡Œçš„æ›¿ä»£æ–¹æ¡ˆæ˜¯Â /etc/openstmpd.confï¼‰ã€‚
table aliases file:/etc/aliases table secrets db:/etc/mail/secrets.db
table sendergnu { jao@gnu.org } table senderjao { mail@jao.io, news@xmobar.org }
listen on localhost

â€œ Happy to introduce you Craftwork 5! ðŸ”¥â€¨
Improved and redesigned up to the most convenient user experience. Now the main page is a catalog where you can browse all the products available on the website. Itâ€™s sorted by the newest assets, so you always see the latest arrivals and the most up-to-date versions of our bestsellers at the top.
Sure, we didn't forget to improve the search flow. You can search for the products you need by categories or keywords. Weâ€™re sure you will find what you need!
New authors from all over the world come to our marketplace every week. Now Craftwork is much more than just a collection of our UI kits, illustrations, and graphics. We are growing and adding huge design systems, fonts, illustrations, and graphics from top designers and cool agencies. We're always on the lookout for new vendors, so drop us an email at hello@craftwork.design to submit your product to the marketplace.
Craftwork always reflects our own taste and style, so it's constantly changing. Now it looks catchy, a little bit bold visually, but still very clear and functional. We really hope you enjoy the new version!
Share your opinion in the comments, we will be glad to hear your feedback and will be happy to know if you like Craftwork 5 as we do!â€¨â€¨Feel free to apply a -30% promo code from the appropriate button ðŸ˜‰

entry.title: A sysadmin's guide to network interface configuration files
entry.summary:
A sysadmin's guide to network interface configuration files David Both Wed, 08/03/2022 - 03:00
2 readers like this 2 readers like this In the first article of this series, Get started with NetworkManager on Linux,Â I looked at what NetworkManager does and some of the tools it provides for viewing network connections and devices. I discussed using the nmcli command to view the status of network devices and connections on a host. I also mentioned that NetworkManager does not need interface configuration files for most hosts. However, it can create its own INI-style connection configuration files, and it recognizes the older and now deprecated network interface configuration files. This article explores three questions: Why do I not use interface configuration files? Why do I use interfaâ€¦

entry.title: Axentix 2.0 â€” Framework leaving the design choice to the developer
entry.summary:
Why Axentix
After using a lot of different frameworks and never be satisfied using them, Axentix has been created. The main goal is to give optionable & customizable components and let the design choice to the developer using the utility classes. All this has been made while making it the most easy to learn and with 0 dependencies.
What's new
ðŸŽ¨ Customization enhancement: Add your own color to the palette and its 9 variants will be generated. Every component comes with CSS Variables making you able to custom each of them.
ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸŽ“ Fast to learn, read and write : Axentix's class names are easy to read, write and learn. If you already used another framework, you already know a plenty of them.
ðŸš€ A lot of new components: Featuring waves, skeleton loading, theme switcher & dark mode handling...
ðŸŒˆ New design trends: Neumorphism, claymorphism & glassmorphism design are already integrated in Axentix !
Future
The future of the framework depends on the community and your advices and feature requests ! Feel free to ask for any help, request or feedback. â€

entry.title: Open source SAML SSO (by BoxyHQ) â€” Integrate enterprise SSO with just a few lines of code
entry.summary:
https://boxyhq.com/)
Weâ€™re excited to see our vision to pioneer enterprise readiness come to life with our first product, SAML Jackson.
ðŸ¤”Problem:
Enterprise customers demand a certain level of security with their services. One of these is SAML authentication so they can manage access using their own permissions.
The problem with this is that building a SAML integration takes a long time and you need to build an integration for each of your customer's identity providers (IdP). This takes your team's focus away from your core product and requires a lot of resources.
ðŸ’¡Solution:
SAML Jackson by BoxyHQ removes the pain of enterprise readiness by offering an out-of-the-box solution for deploying SAML quickly and efficiently. All you need to do is connect your product to BoxyHQ and we manage everything else for you. As if that was not enough, we connect to almost every IdP so you can go from the first line of code to fully support SAML in as little as a week!
Key features: ðŸ¤ Integrate SAML using your favorite OAuth 2.0 or OpenID Connect libraries ðŸ”¨ Single integration with an instant connection to most IdPs â˜‘ï¸ Open-source ðŸ–¥ï¸ Admin UI to ease your customer support issues around SAML setup ðŸŽ¨ Custom support and advice on your setup ðŸ“ Extensive documentation
ðŸ’¬ Feedback SAML Jackson is now live, and weâ€™re looking forward to your thoughts and feedback, The team will be available to answer any questions you may have ðŸ™Œ â€

entry.title: How I use the Linux sed command to automate file edits
entry.summary:
How I use the Linux sed command to automate file edits Jim Hall Tue, 08/02/2022 - 03:00
4 readers like this 4 readers like this When I use the Linux command line, whether I'm writing a new program on my desktop computer or managing a website on my web server, I often need to process text files. Linux provides powerful tools that I leverage to get my work done. I frequently use sed, an editor that can modify text according to a pattern. sed stands for stream editor, and it edits text in a file and prints the results. One way to use sed is to identify several occurrences of one string in a file and replace them with a different string. You can use sed to process text files to a seemingly endless degree, but I'd like to share a few ways I use sed to help me manage files. Search and replâ€¦

entry.title: How I disabled IPv6 on Linux
entry.summary:
How I disabled IPv6 on Linux David Both Mon, 08/01/2022 - 03:00
3 readers like this 3 readers like this IPv6 is a good thing for the Internet in general, but I find it unnecessarily complex for use in most home and small- to medium-size businesses. Like many others, I continue to use private IPv4 address ranges for my own internal networks and those for which I have some level of responsibility. My ISP only provides IPv4 addresses anyway, so it makes no sense to use IPv6 internally when all external packets are IPv4. Besides, IPv4 is much simpler, and one of my Linux Philosophy tenets is "Find the Simplicity." As a result, I disabled IPv6 on all my hosts. It seemed easyâ€”at first. Here is how I did it.
More Linux resources Linux commands cheat sheet Advanced Linux commands cheat sheeâ€¦

entry.title: Why program management matters in open source
entry.summary:
Why program management matters in open source Ben Cotton Mon, 08/01/2022 - 03:00
2 readers like this 2 readers like this Everyone does program management. Some just do it poorly. I've used that line for a laugh at the beginning of talks, but it's true. Program management is, at its core, the act of coordinating the interfaces between teams to produce something of value. In open source projects, the "something of value" is generally the software that the community produces. Most open source communities create software, and almost none of them have a formal program manager. So why have a program manager? The difference lies in managing the software development with intent instead of by accident. The smaller the community, the easier it is to self-coordinate. The need for intentional coâ€¦

entry.title: Learn Rust by debugging Rust
entry.summary:
Learn Rust by debugging Rust Gaurav Kamathe Fri, 07/29/2022 - 03:00
1 reader likes this 1 reader likes this In my previousÂ article about rustup, I showed you how to install the Rust toolchain. Well, what good is the toolchain if you wonâ€™t be using it to get more hands-on with Rust? Learning any language involves reading existing code and writing a lot of sample programs. That's a good way to become proficient in a language. However, there's a third way: debugging code. Learning through debugging involves trying to compile a pre-written (buggy) sample program, understanding the errors generated by the compiler, fixing the sample code, and then re-compiling it. Repeat that process until the code successfully compiles and runs. Rustlings is an open source project by the Rust team that hâ€¦

entry.title: Fix bugs in Bash scripts by printing a stack trace
entry.summary:
Fix bugs in Bash scripts by printing a stack trace Evan "Hippy" Slatis Fri, 07/29/2022 - 03:00
4 readers like this 4 readers like this No one wants to write bad code, but inevitably bugs will be created. Most modern languages like Java, JavaScript, Python, etc., automatically print a stack trace when they encounter an unhandled exception, but not shell scripts. It would make it much easier to find and fix bugs in shell scripts if you could print a stack trace, and, with a little work, you can. Shell scripts can span multiple files, and well-written code is further broken down into functions. Tracing issues when something goes wrong in a shell script can be difficult when these scripts get large enough. A stack trace that walks the code backward from the error to the beginning can shoâ€¦

entry.title: Casama â€” Share your crypto trading ideas, invest together in minutes
entry.summary:
@gerwin_fricke, @slava_tschurilin & @moritz_lochner here â€“ weâ€™re super excited to launch Casama:
ðŸ’° What is Casama? Casama lets you create crypto trade positions that can be funded and executed as a group in minutes â€“ no browser extensions, no complex settings. So you can share trading ideas with your friends and get a management fee if it performs well.
ðŸ”¥ Why did we start Casama? Have you ever posted a trading idea in a group chat without actually ever acting on it? As crypto natives, we want to move fast on good trades. Instead of having vague discussions, back and forth decisions and potentially out on alpha ðŸ˜±
That's why we built Casama â€“ to decide on actionable trades together with skin in the game.
ðŸ§­ So far weâ€™ve built: - Wizard to deploy investment pools with custom settings - Simple web-based wallet to interact with pools - Top-up via PayPal to convert fiat ($) to stablecoin (USDC) - Swapping integration to buy and trade tokens
âš¡ï¸ Inviting friends and pooling funds in minutes â€“ how is it possible?
Thatâ€™s right, invite your friends and pool funds as easy as starting a group chat and paying with PayPal. We conceal complex hashes and automate all the tedious transactions so you don't have to do them.
ðŸ™ Your feedback is gold to us â€“ please share any questions, ideas and comments below. We're just kicking things off and would love hear from fellow makers! The team (of currently 5) is working heads down to improve the UX and features based on your input. Finally, the first 50 deposits get $20 for depositing $10!
Website: https://www.casama.io/ â€
Discussion | Link

entry.title: OpenBB Bot â€” Investment research with the community has never been easier
entry.summary:
openbb.co/products/bot
From being an open source company, we understand the value that customization brings to users. Thus, it has been a priority for us when developing OpenBB Bot. This can be seen from the charts which can be customizable to show your preferred technical analysis indicators or from the fact that you can set your own alerts when your asset of choice hits a certain value.
Note that the OpenBB Bot was built on top of the famous OptionsFamBot which can reach over 1 Million users already, and on top of GamestonkTerminal Bot.
Let us know what sort of data you are interested in seeing, and we can prioritize accordingly.
Are you a server owner on Discord? Get started with OpenBB Bot today: openbb.co/bot-discord
Investment research for everyone, anywhere. â€
Discussion | Link

entry.title: Use this nifty Unix tool to process text on Linux
entry.summary:
Use this nifty Unix tool to process text on Linux Jim Hall Thu, 07/28/2022 - 03:00
3 readers like this 3 readers like this Unix has always excelled at processing text, and Linux is no different. And the tools to work with and transform text files still exist on all Linux systems. Like other computer systems, early Unix printed on paper, using a typewriter-style printing device. These printers provided limited formatting options, but with clever application of Unix tools, you could prepare professional-looking documents. One such tool was the pr tool, to prepare text documents for printing. Let's explore how to use standard Unix tools, such as the pr processor and the fmt text formatter, to prepare text files for printing on a typewriter-style printer. [ Read also:Â How I use the Linuxâ€¦

entry.title: How I manage files from the Linux command line
entry.summary:
How I manage files from the Linux command line Jim Hall Wed, 07/27/2022 - 03:00
4 readers like this 4 readers like this Managing files in a graphical desktop like GNOME or KDE is an exercise in point-and-click. To move a file into a folder, you click and drag the icon to its new home. To remove a file, you drag it into the â€œTrashâ€ icon. The graphical interface makes desktop computing easy to use. But we don't always interact with Linux systems with a graphical interface. If you work on a server, you likely need to use the command line to get around. Even desktop users like me might prefer to interact with their system through a terminal and command line. I tend to rely on a few commands to manage my files from the command line: List files with Linux ls For anyone who uses the commandâ€¦
